name: Roman
content:
Roman

adjective
 
/ˈrəʊmən/
 
/ˈrəʊmən/
jump to other results
  1. connected with ancient Rome or the Roman Empire
    • a Roman road/temple/villa
    • Roman Britain
    Culture Roman BritainRoman BritainThe Romans occupied Britain from around 55 BC to AD 410 and there are still many signs of the occupation at archaeological sites and Roman roads and walls stretching across the countryside.Julius Caesar came to Britain in 55 BC and 54 BC, defeating some of the local Celtic tribes and introducing taxes and establishing trade. When, in AD 43, this was under threat, the emperor Claudius ordered an invasion and southern Britain became Britannia, a province of the Roman Empire which was ruled by a Roman governor. In AD 78 the governor Agricola brought Wales under Roman control, but failed to conquer the Picts and other Scottish tribes in the north. The emperor Hadrian visited Britain in AD 122 and after that Hadrian's Wall, much of which can still be seen today, was built between Newcastle-upon-Tyne and Bowness marking the northern border of the province.The Romans founded over 20 large towns called coloniae, including Colchester which was built as the new capital, Gloucester and Lincoln. It took many years before a town had all the things expected by a Roman citizen, such as a forum (= meeting place) with shops and a town hall, and baths and theatres, which were all highly decorated. London developed first as a trading centre and became the focus for several roads, soon replacing Colchester as the capital. Many roads were built to transport soldiers to border areas and for travel between towns, the most famous of which are Watling Street which ran from Dover to London and then on to St Albans and Chester, Ermine Street between London and York and the Fosse Way which ran from Exeter to Lincoln.By AD 410, when Roman officials left Britain, the country had already been attacked by the picts and invaded by Germanic tribes from northern Europe. More soldiers were sent to defend the province, but when part of the army was moved to deal with trouble elsewhere, the British rebelled against Roman rule and Roman influence declined. Germanic settlers, the Angles, Saxons and Jutes, began arriving in Britain from about AD 430 and took over much of the south and east of the country.
    Topics Historya2
  2. connected with the modern city of Rome
  3. connected with the Roman Catholic Church
  4. roman
     used to describe ordinary printing type that does not lean forward
    • Definitions in this dictionary are printed in roman type.
    compare italic
    5. Word OriginMiddle English: from Old French Romain, from Latin Romanus, from Roma ‘Rome’.
See Roman in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Roman
matches: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
relatives: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

name: Roman
content:
Roman

noun
 
/ˈrəʊmən/
 
/ˈrəʊmən/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. [countable] a member of the ancient Roman republic or empire
  2. [countable] a person from the modern city of Rome
  3. roman
     [uncountable] the ordinary style of printing that uses small letters that do not lean forward compare italics
    4. Word OriginMiddle English: from Old French Romain, from Latin Romanus, from Roma ‘Rome’.
Idioms
when in Rome (do as the Romans do)
  1. (saying) used to say that when you are in a foreign country, or a situation you are not familiar with, you should behave in the way that the people around you behave
See Roman in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

matches: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
relatives: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

name: Roman numeral
content:
Roman numeral

noun
 
/ˌrəʊmən ˈnjuːmərəl/
 
/ˌrəʊmən ˈnuːmərəl/
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
    one of the letters used by the ancient Romans to represent numbers and still used today, in some situations. In this system I = 1, V = 5, X = 10, L = 50, C = 100, D = 500, M = 1 000 and these letters are used in combinations to form other numbers.
    • Henry VIII
    • © BBC MMXIX (2019)
    • If further sub-divisions are required, small Roman numerals can be used.
    compare Arabic numeral
See Roman numeral in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Roman numeral

name: Roman Catholic
content:
Roman Catholic

adjective
 
/ˌrəʊmən ˈkæθlɪk/
 
/ˌrəʊmən ˈkæθlɪk/
(also Catholic)
jump to other results
  1. belonging to or connected with the part of the Christian Church that has the pope as its leader
    Oxford Collocations DictionaryRoman Catholic is used with these nouns:
    • archbishop
    See full entry
Check pronunciation: Roman Catholic

name: Roman Catholic
content:
Roman Catholic

noun
 
/ˌrəʊmən ˈkæθlɪk/
 
/ˌrəʊmən ˈkæθlɪk/
(also Catholic)
(abbreviation RC)
jump to other results
  1. a member of the part of the Christian Church that has the Pope as its leader
    CultureThe Roman Catholic Church was the established Church in Britain until the reformation of the 16th century, when it was replaced by the Protestant Church of England and Church of Scotland. After this Roman Catholics were not permitted to hold public positions or receive university education. In the 19th century the Emancipation Act led to greater religious freedom, but Roman Catholics still cannot be chosen for some high positions in public life, and the king or queen may not practise the religion. The Catholic religion is the main religion in the Republic of Ireland, and there has been violent conflict between Protestants and Catholics in Northern Ireland. The Catholic Church in the United Kingdom is led by the Archbishop of Westminster, the Archbishop of Glasgow and the Archbishop of Armagh.
    Topics Religion and festivalsc2
    Word Originlate 16th cent.: translation of Latin (Ecclesia) Romana Catholica (et Apostolica) ‘Roman Catholic (and Apostolic Church)’. It was apparently first used as a conciliatory term in place of the earlier Roman, Romanist, or Romish, considered derogatory.
See Roman Catholic in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee Roman Catholic in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: Roman Catholic

name: Graeco-Roman wrestling
content:
Graeco-Roman wrestling

noun
 
/ˌɡriːkəʊ ˌrəʊmən ˈreslɪŋ/,
 
/ˌɡrekəʊ ˌrəʊmən ˈreslɪŋ/
 
/ˌɡrekəʊ ˌrəʊmən ˈreslɪŋ/
(North American English usually Greco-Roman wrestling)
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. a form of wrestling in which those taking part are not allowed to hold each other below the middle part of the body Topics Sports: other sportsc2

name: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
content:
The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

 
/ðə dɪˌklaɪn ən ˌfɔːl əv ðə ˌrəʊmən ˈempaɪə(r)/
 
/ðə dɪˌklaɪn ən ˌfɔːl əv ðə ˌrəʊmən ˈempaɪər/
jump to other results
  1. a historical work in six books (1776-88) written by the English historian Edward Gibbon. It covers the history of Europe from Rome in the first century AD to the fall of Constantinople in 1453. Its full title is The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, but it is usually referred to simply as Gibbon's Decline and Fall
Check pronunciation: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
nearBys: The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

name: catholic
content:
catholic

adjective
 
/ˈkæθlɪk/
 
/ˈkæθlɪk/
jump to other results
  1. Catholic
    (also Roman Catholic)
     belonging to or connected with the part of the Christian Church that has the Pope as its leader
    • Are they Catholic or Protestant?
    • a Catholic church
    Topics Religion and festivalsc1
  2. (often Catholic)
     (specialist) connected with all Christians or the whole Christian Church
  3. (formal) including many or most things
    • to have catholic tastes (= to like many different things)
    4. Word Originlate Middle English (in senses (1 and 2)): from Old French catholique or late Latin catholicus, from Greek katholikos ‘universal’, from kata ‘in respect of’ + holos ‘whole’.
See catholic in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: catholic
matches: the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development
relatives: the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development
nearBys: the Catholic Agency for Overseas Development
